org.ndnx.ndn.protocol
Class NDNTime

java.lang.Object
  java.util.Date
      java.sql.Timestamp
          org.ndnx.ndn.protocol.NDNTime
All Implemented Interfaces:
Serializable, Cloneable, Comparable<Date>, ContentName.ComponentProvider
public class NDNTime
extends Timestamp
implements ContentName.ComponentProvider

NDN has a time representation for versions and signing times that is quantized at a granularity of 2^-12 seconds (approximately 1/4 msec). Because it does not quantize time evenly on millisecond boundaries, this can lead to confusion -- t = System.currentTimeMillis(), when used to set a version v, for example, then ends up with v != t as v is quantized and t isn't. Simply providing quantization utility routines to help developers turned out to be error-prone. So we are moving all uses of time in NDN to pre-quantized NDNTime objects, which encapsulates NDN time quantization (which could change), and gives developers ways to deal with it without having to think about it. NDNTime, all though it implements methods like getNanos, only represents time with a granularity equal to the underlying NDN wire format -- i.e. ~.25 msec.

See Also:

NDNTime

public NDNTime()
Creates a NDNTime initialized to the current time.

NDNTime

protected NDNTime(long msec,
                  long nanos)
Creates a NDNTime from a specification of msec and nanos, to ease implementing compatibility with Timestamp and Date. Note that there is redundant data here -- the last 3 significant digits of msec are also represented as the top 3 of nanos. We take the version in the nanos. This is derived from Java's slightly odd Timestamp handling.

Parameters:
msec - milliseconds
nanos - nanoseconds

NDNTime

protected NDNTime(long binaryTimeAsLong,
                  boolean unused)
Creates a NDNTime from the internal long representation of the quantized time. Equivalent to setFromBinaryTimeAsLong.

Parameters:
binaryTimeAsLong - the time in our internal units
unused - a marker parameter to separate this from another constructor

toBinaryTimeAsLong

public static long toBinaryTimeAsLong(long msec,
                                      long nanos)
Static method to convert from milliseconds and nanoseconds to our internal long representation. Assumes that nanos also contains the integral milliseconds for this time. Ignores msec component in msec.

Parameters:
msec - milliseconds
nanos - nanoseconds
Returns:

setNanos in class Timestamp

addNanos

public void addNanos(int nanos)
Note: you have to use a relatively high value of nanos before you get across a quantization unit and have an impact. Our units are 2^-12 seconds, or ~250 msec. So 250000 nanos.

Parameters:
nanos -

increment

public void increment(int timeUnits)
A helper method to increment to avoid collisions. Add a number of NDNx quantized time units to the time. Synchronize if modifications can be performed from multiple threads.

equals

public boolean equals(Timestamp ts)
We handle all comparison functions by quantizing the thing we are being compared to, then comparing. The only thing this won't catch is if a normal Timestamp or Date's comparison method is called with a NDNTime as an argument. This is a small risk, and worth it given the convenience of subclassing Timestamp and using it for most functionality.

Overrides:
equals in class Timestamp

toShortString

public String toShortString()
Generate a string representation of a NDNTime containing only date and HH:MM:SS, not milliseconds or nanoseconds.

getComponent

public final byte[] getComponent()
Convert the time into a version component, so NDNTime objects can be used directly in a ContentName builder.

Specified by:
getComponent in interface ContentName.ComponentProvider
Returns:
Fetches a component. The byte array that is returned must be immutable - i.e. never get changed. If there is any risk the byte array you have may be changed you must return a new copy of it.
